The reality is that casualisation of the work force has been an accelerating trend since 1982 and these regulations will only accelerate the speed of that change even further. ACIRRT, which recently did a research program, made the point that the decline in job security that Australians have experienced since the late 1980s is equivalent to about a 13 per cent drop in income. That is a very significant point.

speech.para: The other point I want to draw attention to relates to the six-month probationary period. What an absurd proposition. What an absolutely absurd proposition to require that, in many industries, an employee must be employed for six months before an employer can make a value judgment about the work of that employee in the company. It is an absolutely absurd proposition.

We had evidence given to the committee by the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association about the level of training that is required for an employee to be engaged in that industry. I think they said that a very short period of probation of a couple of weeks for a full timer and maybe a bit longer for a part timer would be more than adequate in terms of the skill base required for the vast majority of employees in the retail industry. They made the point, as is made in this Bulletin article, that the introduction of the regulation for the six-month probationary period will only add to churning in the industry. You will create a set of circumstances where employers will be able to take employees on, train them for a short period to give them the skills and employ them for 5½ months to avoid any obligation in terms of unfair dismissal, then they will simply turn them over, sack them for being inadequate for the job, employ new employees and go through the same process again with very little disruption to their business but with a very substantial protection of their interests. It is interesting to note that the issue of churning of job seekers is referred to in this Bulletin article. It says:

The churning of job seekers between low-quality, dead-end jobs and unemployment, identified in a landmark ABS study, leaves little room for optimism. The ABS followed 875,000 job seekers from May 1995 to September 1996 and found that about 70% of them worked for some period, but 66% of their jobs were casual and 90% were short-term.

Again, the passage of these regulations will simply accelerate the trend of employers churning employees through their businesses to avoid their obligations in respect of unfair dismissals. The reality is that the laws that were introduced in 1995 did help to redress the balance between employer and employee and did bring a degree of fairness into the system. But if these regulations are passed, it will make the system fair to employers and totally unfair to employees who have got to survive in the system and earn a living out of it.

talk.start.para: —It is interesting to follow Senator George Campbell in this debate. Obviously, he is coming from a union background. I always like to listen to another point of view, and I hope he listens to mine.

speech.para: In 1966, after a year of marriage, I decided that I would have to either accept a wage or go out and cut my cloth. I took the latter option and started my own small business. I started from a very humble beginning. I could afford a $750 VW which I took the back seats out of to put samples in, and I established myself as a manufacturer's agent. My wife was the storeman and packer, the receptionist and the telephonist, and I was the salesman. After collecting the orders during the day, my wife finished teaching and we proceeded to both become storemen and packers because we could not afford a storeman and packer. That is how we grew. Before I came into the Senate, I employed 10 people. Senator Campbell, I would really appreciate it if you would stay to listen to this.

talk.start.para: —I am listening.

—We employed storemen and packers, typists, clerks and so forth. There seems to be a misunderstanding, a misapprehension, in the Labor Party that employers want to dismiss people. In fact, if you get anyone half good, you want to keep them and you do not want to dismiss them. As for saying that you can employ people, keep them for six months and then when they have been trained—and it costs you a lot of money to get them up to speed and make them effective in their job—you dismiss them and churn them over, that just is not reasonable. What you try to do is employ someone and train them in six months and then they become more valuable to you.
—They are not all scrupulous employers out there.

—No, I accept there are always rogue employers, there are always rogue unions and there are always rogue unionists, but we cannot as a government legislate for rogues who are probably going to make up two per cent of the people. I am sorry to say this to you, because I think you are coming from a very genuine position. I know if I owned a business now, I would be very reluctant to put someone on. If you do put someone on in your small business and you cannot put them off, you effectively are putting yourself—
—You can put them off. You just can't treat them unfairly.
—You can't put them off.
—Of course you can.

—The procedure to put someone off—and you know this as well as I do. Please let me finish this. I did not interrupt you. I feel very passionate about this. If you put people off, you have to go through a fairly long process that can, and usually does, end up going to court where you have to pay a fairly small amount—$3,000 or $4,000 or $7,000—but the whole process takes a long time. It cannot be effected immediately. I have heard of people actually having their hand in the till, so to speak, and even then you cannot dismiss the person.

speech.para: What you are trying to do here will have a reverse effect. We are all trying to employ people. It does not matter which side of the House we are on, we all acknowledge that unemployment is an evil. It is an evil particularly when it gets imposed on young people, and we want to avoid that. No-one wants unemployment out there at any level—whether it is three, four or eight per cent.

But everyone is totally reluctant to put an employee on, because what happens if he is a dud. You have to carry him. You almost have to go and get legal advice to remove him. It makes you ineffective because you may have to carry him for six to nine months. You can't put on someone else, because he is effectively the person that you have employed. You don't have any more money to put another person on.

You can't just say, `I've got him there at $25,000 a year and he is no good. Therefore, I have to find another $25,000 a year to put someone else on to do his job, and I will just leave him sitting in a corner,' because most small businesses are running on very tight margins. If you cannot get someone who works properly, you just cannot afford to put someone else on—unless you are the government, a very big business or someone like Telstra or Australia Post that can effectively say, `Look, Fred, you go over there and just don't worry us.' When you are down to 10 employees, it has to be all hands and the cook. Everyone has to be up there doing their job. If you cannot dismiss someone, then you are effectively making the business redundant—the whole business goes down.

What I am saying to you, Senator Campbell, is that you are really hurting the people that you are trying to help—the young people that are looking for jobs. There are many small business people out there—I know them and I mix with them. I go to National Party meetings with small business people. They always come up with this problem, `We would put someone on, but what if he is a dud?' You are saying that we are getting into casualisation. I would say that this is promoting casualisation.

talk.start.para: —It is the facts.
—I am not doubting the facts. You were quoting the facts. I am not doubting what you are saying.

speech.para: But if you cannot employ someone to do a job without removing them if they cannot do the job, what is your next option? The next option is to bypass your responsibility and say, `I'm not going to do that. I'm not going to put that person on to do that particular job of photostatting or some other job. I will get it done outside and it is their problem if they can't get an employee that works. I will pass that across. I will subcontract that part of my business out.'

I do not dispute for a minute what you have said about casualisation—your facts are obviously right—but I am saying that you are adding to the problem of casualisation. I have the figures here. Small business accounted for 42 per cent of all employment. There are about 900,000 small businesses in Australia that make up about 86 per cent of all the businesses. What you are effectively doing by disallowing this piece of legislation is making people in business say, `I am going to run at the absolute meanest that I can. If that means I have to subcontract out, I will do it.'

In her speech today Senator Jacinta Collins quoted from a New South Wales Chamber of Commerce survey which indicated that half the small businesses entangled in unfair dismissal claims said they were not going to hire new staff. At what point do we then understand that, if the Chamber of Commerce is saying that half of its people will not put labour on because they are frightened or they have been bitten—

talk.start.para: —No, that is not what those figures say. Half of the people have been involved in the claims. You heard from the statistics that it was the best part of very few. So not half their members. Half of the people who have been involved in claims.
—I have listened to your interjection, but the Chamber of Commerce said that half of the small businesses entangled under unfair dismissal claims were deterred from hiring new staff.

speech.para: Senator Jacinta Collins interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Collins is denying that she said it. I took it down as she said it. Whether she said it or not—she denies she said it.
—That is not what I said—not the way you expressed it.

—The facts are that the Chamber of Commerce, which I suppose is the main representative body of small business—and big business for that matter—is saying that people who have been bitten by this just will not go out and hire anyone else. I have listened to this debate—
—Read Rob Bastian's evidence.
—I have spoken to Rob Bastian. I know him well.
—He is a lot closer to small business than ACCI.

—They are a lot closer than ACCI. But every time I see Rob Bastian—and that is probably once every three or four weeks—he says to me that we have to fix this unfair dismissals system because it is the greatest load on small business.
—But you are not fixing it.
—We are fixing it; you are not fixing it by moving a disallowance motion. Rob Bastian is saying, `Yes, it is a big problem.' He is saying there are other problems, but this is a huge problem.

speech.para: If you went out and conducted a survey amongst small businesses, including those in rural areas, you would find overwhelmingly that people would list `unfair dismissal' as their number one fear—and big businesses would too. But big businesses can avoid it. If big businesses such as Myers or Coles have a dud, they put that person into some job he does not like and perhaps he will leave, or they leave him in a corner. If you employ 10,000 or more people, like Coles, then it does not make much difference.

But, for goodness sake, realise that there are not that many Coles, Woolworths and Telstras around. Eighty-six per cent of business is small business. You are putting lead in their saddlebags, and they just will not employ. Both sides of this House are coming from the same direction: we all want to see more employment. You are saying that you can do it by stopping people dismissing people; and I am saying that you cannot do it that way.

As someone who has employed people—it was not a large number of people; I was a very small business person who employed 10 people; in the agency game in those days, I suppose it was in the top 80 per cent—I want you to think very clearly about what I am now going to tell you: you cannot legislate to stop people from acting in a certain way. There are and always will be rogue employers. But, if people do not like them, they can walk away and get another job. There will always be people who do the wrong thing—and I know that.

But the majority of small business people are not rogues. What they want is an employee who gives them loyalty and long service, someone who will turn up to work five days a week when they are not sick. They welcome employees of that sort because they are the backbone of their business. Those sorts of people are needed out there in the workplace.

I am very disappointed that Senator Murray is not here because this measure will swing on his vote. But I know this, just as I know that night follows day—because I have been there and not for one year but for 18 years. If you disallow this motion, you will condemn at least 50,000 people to unemployment. If you let this motion go through, I will put my reputation on the line and guarantee that you will see small business employing more people. We all have to change; we come here with fixed attitudes.

talk.start.para: —Why do you resort to a fear campaign?

—I am not getting into any fear campaign. I have been there, Senator Bolkus. I know what I am talking about. I have had 18 years of experience. I am talking from personal experience, from a background of small business. I am talking on behalf of the National Party, which is small business oriented.

speech.para: When I go out into the marketplace, into the National Party meetings—just as you go to your party meetings every Saturday—this is one of the main things I am told by the owner of the local Mitre 10 store, or the owner of the tractor distribution, or the grocery store owner: `Look, we'd put more people on, but it's too risky. The process of dismissing these people is too risky. It takes three letters, then we end up in court, and we end up paying $17,000. We could go and process it, we could proceed. We would probably win the case, but it would cost us another $40,000. So we are just very happy to pay $17,000.' They only have to go through that once or twice, and they just say, `We're going to stick with what we've got. We'll get the wife in and she can answer the phone, and as people leave we will retract.' I am telling you: this is coming from small business.

When you go to your ALP meetings, you have unionists and different people there. They are probably telling you something different. But I am giving it to you straight from the horse's mouth: do not disallow this motion and you will increase employment, and you will see many more people having jobs in the small business sector.

talk.start.para: —Australia—including this government, unfortunately—is doing what a number of countries are doing at the moment. That is, international corporations, companies, are playing off one country against the other for the lowest standards in the workplace. And Australia is falling for it; this government is falling for it.

speech.para: We have heard today about `the will of the people'. How many people in Australia, if asked, would say that they would be happy to increase their job insecurity? How many people, if asked, would say that at the moment, with this current government, they feel more certain about their future?

The reality is that the driving force, the prime driving force, for small business employing people is the people who come through the door to buy their goods and services. Those people in the vast majority of small businesses in Australia, the ordinary working people of Australia, are consumers as well. They are not just costs of production. In order for their making the decision to purchase the goods and services of small business, they have to know that they are going to have a job. Provided that they do their job reasonably and fairly, they need to have that certainty or security that they are not going to be treated unfairly; that there is not the climate around of governments encouraging their employers to treat them simply as a disposable cost of production.

If you want to do something for small business in Australia, you do something for the security and the certainty of life for the vast majority of people who are not only the workers in business but also the purchasers of goods and services in other businesses. This is not just a cost issue. It is about the ability of people to make decisions about where they spend their dollars—whether they get their windows cleaned, whether they get their cars serviced, whether they buy those extra goods and services, whether they think they can afford it next week in the belief that they will still have a job.

Here we are debating the issue of unfair dismissal provisions for employees in the small business sector for the nth time. In simple terms, I can state from the outset that the Greens position has not changed from the previous occasions that we have debated this question, and the answer is still no. I would like to commend Senator Murray for his excellent appraisal of the actual statistics of the impacts of unfair dismissal legislation in Australia.

On the previous occasions we debated this issue, a reading of Hansard will indicate that I have pursued similar themes. I will remind the Senate of some of these comments. On 18 November 1996, in relation to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Bill 1996, I quoted from Justice Murray Wilcox, who said:

We meet regularly in the court with representatives of both employers and employees to review the way the court administers its affairs, and business groups suggest that things are working very smoothly.
Again, on the previous night on the 7.30 Report Justice Wilcox commented:

They are at odds with bad business, and the problem is that there are too many bad managers who do not have enough respect for their employees and there are people that suffer awards against them. I mean, really, you would be appalled at some of the cases.

I listened to Senator Boswell's contribution. The indications are that Senator Boswell, from the sound of it, would not be the kind of employer who would treat his employees unfairly. This legislation is not going to affect employers who do not treat their employees unfairly. Certainly, there has been a fear campaign to make people think there is something to be concerned about. On 26 June 1997 in relation to workplace relations regulations I stated:

We have to look at integrated policies. We have to look at what is causing structural unemployment. We have to look at the kinds of business and corporate decisions and directions and policy decisions that are causing structural unemployment in this country. Instead of dealing with that, once again we are pointing to those people who are most affected by those decisions, and we are saying, `If only business could be allowed to treat employees more unfairly,' and, `If only you would let us make sure that contracts are not binding for employers but are binding only for employees, then things would be okay.'

I remind the Senate that what we are being asked to do—and we have also been asked to make sure that as many employees as possible are on contracts—is say that these contracts are one-way contracts. The only person who has to keep the contract is the employee. But, if they maintain their contract, the employer can break it. It is a one-way contract. This is what the government says is fair. Contracts are important if they are between businesses. Contracts are important if you make them to businesses, but if businesses require you to sign a contract, it is not binding on business.

It is the most disastrous idea if you think that what is important is to force people on to contracts. It has never been my opinion that we should be forcing people on to contracts. The conservative side of the chamber says that we will do better if we force people on to contracts, and that will be fair for everyone. How can it be fair if you say these contracts must not be binding on small business? We force people on to contracts, but we are prepared to say that these contracts must not be binding, only binding in one direction.
On 21 October in relation to the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 I stated:

I believe that many people have been hoodwinked into believing that there is a massive problem with unfair dismissal and that business, especially small business, is being hamstrung by unworkable regulations with respect to the dismissal of their employees.
I believe that what is not being taken into consideration is the major issues affecting small business, that is, getting people through their door.

We heard today figures quoted of people who have had unfair dismissal claims. Those people are cited as the basis for half of small business being concerned about this. The reality is that the actual number of people who have made a claim is very, very small as a percentage. Of those, half of them seem to be happy that that is not the reason for making their decisions in the future about employment. We do not have any statistics about how many of those claims were fair or how many of those people were treated unfairly. Why should we stick up for those people who may be abusing the law and treating their employees unfairly?
On 24 March 1998 in my speech on the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 I stated:

The 1996-97 annual report of the Industrial Relations Court of Australia highlighted that 58 per cent of contested unfair dismissal cases were decided in favour of the employee. Instead of the government saying, as it always seems to, `Oh, gosh, this is a cost for the employer,' I would say, `My goodness, this means that the court has found that 58 per cent of those people were found to have been unfairly dismissed.'

The law was there and it asked what was the basis of unfair dismissal. If 58 per cent of those cases in the 1996-77 annual report were found to be unfair dismissals, then it is a nonsense to suggest that people are simply using the system to rort the system.

How many people really have access to good legal advice? How many people really take action when they are unfairly dismissed? I suggest that a great many people never take action because there is not very free access to labour lawyers. The system is in favour of those people who are employers. If there is a tip of the iceberg, we are probably finding that the iceberg will be seen if we remove these legislative protections, small though they are. We will find that those numbers of people treated unfairly will be the iceberg. It will be the reason why many more people in our society will choose not to buy those services from the very small businesses which this conservative government is hoping will create more employment. In a press statement that I made on 24 September 1998 I said:
"Job security is one of the key concerns of many people in this election. If people have a job, it is now more likely to be casual or part-time—
and we have heard those numbers given today—
and now the Government wants to make it easier to sack people who work in the largest employer group in the country, small business."
"The Government is also ignoring the impact of this growing job insecurity on small businesses themselves."
"This greater level of insecurity amongst workers will mean that they are less likely to spend any savings or disposable income. The greatest loser in that event will be the small business sector."

I know that industrial relations issues are seen to be important to a number of small business interests, but we also know, as we heard from Keynes back in the 1930s, that what is seen to be in the self-interest of an individual employer is not necessarily in the best interest of other employers and not necessarily even in the best interest of the economy. I do not think this government can see the wood for the trees. I do not think this government is looking at it on an economy-wide basis, and I do not think that they have even recognised that the employees of small business are people who make decisions whether to purchase goods and services. They make up the bulk of those people who are making decisions which keep small business in business. So in the interest of small business, in the interest of the economy and also in the interest of justice, the Greens will maintain our position and oppose this portion of the regulations and support the disallowance motion.

talk.start.para: —I will be brief in supporting the motion to disallow these regulations. I am sure it will be suggested by those opposite that somehow our opposition to this legislation has to do with an interest because we are—or, in some cases, have been—members of trade unions and have held positions in trade unions. What I want to remind those opposite is this: these regulations seek to, in effect, take away rights that exist under the legislation of this government for employees, whether members or not of trade unions. I want them to reflect that, in fact, they are taking rights away not from a class of people who are union members but from a class of people who are employees who happen to be employed in small businesses, and all of the material that has been placed before us indicates that there are a great many people employed in small business.

speech.para: If we are to believe what is said, and small business is the generator of new jobs, then there will be thousands and thousands and thousands of employees, present and to come, whose rights are curtailed by the regulations, which were so sneakily put forward, promulgated, by the minister before Christmas. This, of course, is the minister who was quite prepared to be involved in discussions which I think would lead to the view that there was knowledge about the sacking of thousands of waterfront workers because that was a means that suited the end of this minister. In this case, the minister is seeking to achieve an end he cannot achieve legislatively, even tempo rarily, by promulgating a regulation after the parliament rose last year and seeking by means that are unclear to me to somehow get these regulations up.

talk.start.para: —A coward's act.

—I am not really sure that this can be seen as anything other than a deliberate, calculated and even cowardly act by the minister in relation to these regulations. I reject the suggestion that perhaps because I am a member of a trade union somehow I have a special interest in this. We all have a special interest in this legislation because we all represent, or at least purport to represent, those people who voted for us, and there are people who voted for all parties here who would fall within the class of employees who will be disenfranchised, in effect, or who would lose their rights to seek some redress for an unfair act by their employer.

speech.para: All of the argument that the government has put up in this case has been designed to beat up the fears of employers. They are saying, `You really have something to fear from this legislation.' We really have not heard a statistical analysis of the number of employees who were engaged by small business, the number of employees who were dismissed by small business and the number amongst them who actually do pursue their rights. But, if you look at it, the number who actually are dismissed and pursue their rights must be absolutely minimal. Senator Murray laid out some figures for us today in the chamber which indicate that an extremely small percentage of employees who are actually dismissed by small business pursue their right to a remedy.

I am not saying that they are the only people who might have rights to pursue. There would be a great many people who would make the decision, `I do not want to go through the process. I know it is difficult for me.' It may be difficult for the employers, but it is not easy for employees either. It takes a very strong-willed person to pursue their rights in these sorts of proceedings. I have been involved in proceedings, representing employees, and I know how stressful it can be for them because essentially they have to put their credibility on the line, justify their position and have the allegations which are made against them laid out in a public hearing.

So the people who pursue their rights must be fairly strong-minded people to do that, I would suggest, and to succeed they would need a very good case. It is not really as simple as coming up with some anecdotal evidence about someone who allegedly had their hand in the till and got off. I think Senator Boswell attempted to suggest this, to justify this extremely pernicious piece of legislation by regulation.

If this regulation were to stand, what would its effect be on the employment of a number of people in small businesses? Wouldn't it be equally arguable that a number of employers would say, `If I do not dismiss this person by this date then I will become liable to the provisions of the act in relation to unfair dismissal'? So if the government's argument is correct and employers are not engaging staff because they fear they might fall foul of the legislation as it stands or if, at a point in time, a small business employing fewer than 15 people were to become liable to the provisions of this regulation, then the employer might have a vested interest in terminating before that date occurred. That could well be an issue in which the government is actually further encouraging the employers to curtail employment of employees before that occurred.

It really is a case, as Senator Murray so eloquently put it, of the removal of the rights of a class of employees because they happen to be employed in small businesses—without the justification which I think ought to be put forward. For example, why should employees in my state employed under this legislation lose those rights when employees employed under the state legislation working in a business next door maintain those rights? This government may well say that the Tasmanian employees under the state act should lose their rights. But I can tell you that that is not likely to happen in the immediate future. So you create a class of employees who are second-class citizens in terms of their rights.

Bear in mind that the legislation which is, in effect, being altered by this regulation contemplated the rights that exist now. And that is the legislation of this government. So all that the government and this minister are doing is either telling us that they were never serious when they came up with an agreement with the Democrats for provisions in relation to unfair dismissal or that, somehow, there has been some substantial change in circumstances since they came up with the agreement—which was so trumpeted—with the Democrats for the implementation of the provisions of the bill as they now stand. I am not surprised that the Democrats are so incensed at the actions of this government, because I think they believed that they had a deal and that, in effect, this minister is ratting on a deal that he made. He has put forward no justification for doing so. The Democrats, understandably, are furious that the minister is trying to cut the ground from under them when the Democrats said that they had a reasonable deal on unfair dismissal provisions.

I will close on this point: if a minister seeks to have a relationship with parties in this House in respect of negotiations, then he had better come to those negotiations with clean hands. The actions of this minister in relation to these regulations clearly indicate for all to see that the minister is not bound by agreements that he reaches, and that he seeks to undermine part of that agreement he reached with the Democrats by promulgating this regulation. It seems to me that this regulation will fail, that it will be defeated, and I look forward to the vote this evening.

talk.start.para: —I intend to speak briefly to reinforce some of the arguments of my colleagues. We are anxious that this disallowance motion should go to a vote this evening—frankly, the sooner the better. Certainly, I would hope that the disallowance motion is carried and that the regulations that Minister Reith has promulgated are voted down.

speech.para: There is a fundamental principle that is central to this debate on the disallowance motion. That fundamental principle is that all adult Australians have equal access to take an appropriate action before a court or a tribunal in the event that they have been wronged. They have a fundamental right for their case to be heard. To some extent, I know, that is a theoretical access, because it does depend on your ability to pay a lawyer. Nevertheless, this is a fundamental principle and it is one of the central tenets of our Australian society—equality and access to a tribunal in the event of being wronged. It is important in the Australian context as part of the element of what is seen as a fair go.

I do not believe that is a principle that should ever be compromised, and yet that is what Minister Reith and the Liberal Howard government have done with these regulations. They are proposing to exempt from federal wrongful dismissal laws employers who have a work force with 15 or less employees. I emphasise federal, because this will impact only in respect of workplaces covered by federal law. It will not impact on workplaces covered by state law. So you will have two classes, effectively. You will have a class of employees working for small business in the state jurisdictions who can still present a case before a tribunal in the event of an alleged wrongful dismissal. You could have a small business in my home state of Tasmania covered by the state jurisdiction and its employees can take their case to the state industrial commission in Tasmania. A small business next door could have the same class of employees working under the same set of circumstances covered by a federal award. If wrongfully dismissed, those employees cannot present a case before a tribunal.

You could even have the absurd situation where a workplace is covered by a Tasmanian state award and also by a federal award; of one group of employees of that business being able to go to a tribunal in the event of wrongful dismissal and the other group of employees not being able to take their case before a tribunal.

It is interesting to note the constant jibes from the government about the alleged influence of the union movement on our position on this matter. They enjoy highlighting the fact that there are a significant number of people in this place who have union backgrounds. I am one of them. I am proud of that and I do not shy away from it.

What I find interesting about the retreat from the principle that I outlined earlier is that it is coming from a government dominated by lawyers. It is intriguing that lawyers are prepared to remove the fundamental rights of a class of employees to be able to present their case before a tribunal in the event of a wrongful dismissal. What this lawyer dominated government is saying is that regardless of how badly you are treated, how unfairly you are treated, you have no right to present your case before a tribunal. It is a rather strange approach coming from a lawyer dominated government.

What is the rationale for that approach? We get a sweeping set of claims that small business is the engine room of the economy, that Australia needs dynamic growth to reduce unemployment, that 50,000 jobs will be created, although it tends to vary. When you listen to speakers from the government you hear claims anywhere between 20,000, 50,000 and 100,000 jobs. It does tend to vary. They argue that small business should not be burdened by this allegedly dreadful bureaucratic process to protect fundamentally the rights of employees. We do not hear any such concern about the impositions of a GST on small business and the bureaucratic process that small business will be wrapped up in as a consequence of a GST. Fundamentally, it is an assertion from this government, and there is no modelled proof that this assertion is correct.

Why is a Liberal government going down this path? I think it has to find an excuse for not having performed better in the area of unemployment. There is one other fundamental reason. Over the break I think Minister Reith decided that he needed to get back in the leadership stakes. He has to show to the party faithful that he is in there allegedly fighting for small business and employment and bashing the unions. I say that seriously. I think that is part and parcel of Minister Reith's approach. I do not believe that he was particularly confident this regulation was going to survive in the Senate, but he had a go in order to ensure his profile is up there in the leadership stakes.

I conclude by returning to the fundamental principle involved here—that is, all adult employees have a right to put their case before a tribunal if they are wrongfully treated. It is not as though thousands and thousands of former employees are fronting up to small businesses; there is a very small proportion. But they do have that fundamental right in Australian society, and that right should be preserved. These regulations should be voted down.

talk.start.para: —Having failed last year to get these provisions passed through parliament, Mr Reith attempted to slip them through just before Christmas. The introduction of these regulations follows on the heels of an arrogant attempt by Mr Reith to force on the Australian people, without due parliamentary process, unfair dismissals by regulation.

speech.para: As soon as the regulations were gazetted, as soon as this snub of the parliamentary process occurred, serious legal debate in this country began. In the meantime, most workers and the business community were left not knowing where they stood legally in relation to the unfair dismissal laws. We know and we have heard that these regulations will limit the ability of employees to make claims of unfair dismissal. The regulations require a six-month period of employment before new employees can access any remedy and exclude new employees of small business with 15 or fewer employees.

This government argues that it is determined to generate strong and sustained job growth. These regulations do nothing, and last week's Senate inquiry into this area proved that there is no evidence to suggest that job growth will be generated or sustained by the introduction of these regulations.

I want to focus tonight on a section of our community which has not fared well in this debate—that is, the impact these regulations, should they not be disallowed, will have on women. It is likely that these changes will have a large impact on women and their role in the work force. Women are more likely to move in and out of the work force, as we full well know, as their family needs change, as women have more children, as their children grow up and as their needs within their family structure alter with the onset of parents ageing or the introduction of grandchildren into their family. By and large, it is women who alter the nature and the type of work that they perform during their life.

Women enter the work force on a temporary or part-time basis as their family financial needs change. As new short-term employees or as workers for small business, their award rights to appeal on the basis of unfair dismissal will now be removed. Women make up approximately 43 per cent of the Australian work force. A significant proportion of the part-time work force at all levels and across all sectors are women, who make a substantial contribution to our economy. It is women, by and large, who have been forgotten in this debate on the introduction of these regulations.

A significant proportion of women become pregnant during their working lives. Despite the fact that we have had legislation in place that makes discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy illegal, there is evidence that women continue to be disadvantaged when attempting to combine their right to work with their choice to have children. As a result of changes to awards or the introduction of regulations such as the ones we have in front of us, many workers' rights under the industrial award system have been removed.

I note that discrimination on the basis of pregnancy remains one of 20 allowable matters under the new award structure. However, there are many other scenarios whereby women will be affected by the removal of unfair dismissal rights. They are more likely to have responsibility for child care in addition to their employment responsibilities. Yet Mr Reith, in his response to the report of the review of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act, Unfinished business, which I note has yet to be tabled before this parliament, stated, `The coalition government is firmly committed to promoting equal employment opportunities for women.' This statement is in stark contrast to what the government hopes to achieve by having these regulations not disallowed this evening.

In his response to this report, Mr Reith said that the act `provides scope for the development of innovative and flexible workplace agreements on working patterns and leave entitlements'. This, he said, will `enable women to enter into agreements tailored to their personal or family circumstances'. Yet we well know that, by these regulations, women will be severely disadvantaged. Their right to be able to tailor their personal or family circumstances have now been removed. When Mr Reith comments about his Workplace Relations Act and his policy under this government being a fair go for all and a fair go all round, it is women once again who will bear the brunt of the policies of this government.

Senator ALSTON

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak to the motion moved by Senator Faulkner. I commence by saying that, to the extent that Senator Crossin was rabbiting on about how affirmative action was somehow relevant to this particular proposition, you might be interested to know that the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986, introduced by the Hawke government, excludes from its operation employers with fewer than 100 employees. In the second reading speech the Prime Minister of the day acknowledged that small businesses did not have the capacity to undertake the full import of that legislation.

speech.para: Quite clearly, that act recognises that separate circumstances apply to small business. That is the fact, as you all well and truly know. I am surprised that you even have the gall to come in here to try to mount the sorts of specious arguments that you do. It is an absolute litany of union employees doing the bidding of their masters. It is very interesting to note that only a couple of years ago Senator Cook, who was the Labor spokesman on the issue, said to AAP, `We will not be trying to block this legislation in the Senate.' Then he put out a press release explaining what he said at that doorstop:

I may have said that the opposition will try to block the small business unfair dismissal provisions in the Senate. This is not what I meant to convey. Any comment that the opposition would block this legislation in the Senate is not correct.

Why the about-face? Simply because those who call the shots decided that this was not in their best interests. That is why we had Mr Pallas writing as recently as 22 December last year saying that the ACTU is confident that the regulations will be invalidated by the courts in the new year and even more confident that the Senate will disallow them at the earliest opportunity. How did he know that? Because he had stitched it up. He called the troops in. He said, `Right. Do you want your preselections or don't you?'

Look at what they are doing to Brumby. This is tragic. That bloke is being hung out on a rack day after day by union officials saying, `Right. Doesn't deliver on the union agenda. Out he goes.' This is criminal stuff. The guy ought to be allowed to get on with it, play politics as best he can but not have to be humiliated on a daily basis by the union movement. But they clearly have no compunction about doing it to the senators because they own them.

You have come from nowhere. You are simply extending your union careers. You are not prepared to go out in the real world and earn a job in the private sector, so you come into the Senate. It is a nice little retirement home. It has great entitlements in due course. It does not matter if you stay in opposition forever. You do not have to go home and explain what you have been doing all day. You just rake in the dough.

talk.start.para: —What about you at 20 to 12 at night? You should've gone home and explained that.

—My friend, I had another commitment, as you well know, and I kept that commitment; and I went and rang my wife straight after I got out of there and I said to her, `That bloke Faulkner is a nightmare. You wouldn't believe what I've had to go through for the last three hours.' She said, `Why do you put yourself through it?' I said, `The national interest is the only thing that keeps me here. It is an absolute shocker to have to put up with the likes of Faulkner.' She said, `Not that bloke that's on the box all the time like a shark?' I said, `Well, there's a lot of things you could compare him to.'
—You've gone mad.

—I was distracted; I agree. The point of the whole issue is that this is simply yet another attempt by the Labor Party to defend the indefensible. I noticed in Europe recently that there are a couple of classic examples of governments like the Blair government wanting to move on unfair dismissals because they know that it is cramping the style of small business. They know that these things are constantly abused. They know some of the statistics. I am sure that Senator Jacinta Collins, who spends about 14 hours a day in estimates dealing with the most arcane and trivial aspects of industrial relations folklore which she has spent a lifetime absorbing, would know the validity of these statistics.

speech.para: The number of businesses entangled in the federal commission is 16,665. That is the number of federal applications made between the end of 1996 through to 29 January 1999. About 35 per cent of those federal applications in 1998 were small businesses—that is, with 15 or fewer employees. Given that many businesses do not differentiate between federal and state regimes, it is instructive to add together the number of applications made from 1996 to 1998. The total is 55,740. So that is even more than the COSBOA estimate of 50,000 jobs being put on the line because of this sort of legislation.

We know from the evidence before the Senate committee that a large percentage of these claims are settled. Why? They are settled because of commercial reality. Why are they instituted in the first place? Because you and your ilk earn a nice living out of trotting them up to the commission and dealing with them endlessly. Talk about ambulance chasing! This is the union equivalent of ambulance chasing, you see. You take all these things through the court, irrespective of the merits, knowing that, by and large, the poor old employers will say, `We just haven't got the time or inclination to pursue these matters right through to the bitter end. We'll come to a commercial settlement.'

That is what happens. Everyone is held to ransom. You get bogged down in litigation. The last way you want to run your small business is by being distracted by court cases, so people capitulate. That is the great tragedy of all this. You know that it has nothing to do with protecting the genuine rights of those who might otherwise be at risk of wrongful dismissal. This legislation is simply an abuse of process designed to make it extraordinarily difficult for employers to introduce flexibility into their workplace and to make it extraordinarily easy for you and your lot to earn a nice little living by trotting along to the courts on a daily basis.

I do not think we need to maintain this charade any longer. In fact, I congratulate Senator Faulkner; I think he might be the first one from the other side of the chamber to speak in this debate who is not a former full-time trade union employee. I look forward to his remarks. Unfortunately, I think we all know why he has got the job he has got, apart from the fact that Robert Ray had lost the energy and enthusiasm and no-one else was prepared to put their hand up—and, of course, Ray would not have let Cook get it in a fit. So he is sort of there by default. Basically, he is there because the union officials who elected you lot said, `We could cope with Senator Faulkner.' You might cope with him, but we can't.

talk.start.para: —I do not think anyone listening to this debate could believe that the government are serious in arguing their case in relation to this disallowance motion. You just have to hear or read the speech that Senator Alston has made on an important issue of public policy to know the level of contribution that is typical of senior ministers in this government. This is the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. This is the person responsible for mounting the case, representing the industrial relations minister in this chamber, on what I think many Australians would consider to be an important issue. And that is the level of the contribution that we get.

speech.para: Let me make a serious contribution on the substance of the matter before the chamber. I would like to commence my contribution by quoting from the opposition's minority report on the consideration of the provisions of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Unfair Dismissals) Bill 1998, which I think was tabled in this place yesterday. To quote:

1. Our concern remains that the bill contravenes the Prime Minister's key commitment to the Australian people when he claimed that, under his government, employees would not be worse off under his government's industrial relations legislation.
2. Our concern remains that the exemption is unfair.
3. Our concern remains that the exemption is unnecessary.

These three points underpinned our opposition to that legislation—legislation that has been put before this Senate twice, that has been rejected by the Senate twice. But, of course, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business will not accept the will of the Senate, of the parliament. They have subverted the parliamentary process and attempted to introduce the same unfair dismissal exemptions through the back door by regulation.

During the debate on Mr Peter Reith's most recent unfair dismissal exemption legislation in the House of Representatives in December last year, the minister gagged 23 speakers who wished to highlight the unfairness of his bill. Two weeks later, seven days after the parliament had risen for the year, Mr Peter Reith, in his typical sneaky and underhand style, issued a press release to announce the introduction of unfair dismissal regulations for small businesses which employ 15 or fewer people. The following day, on Friday, 18 December, the regulations were gazetted, circumventing proper parliamentary process and obscuring the issue from public view during the Christmas break.

What is the effect of the regulations, which some of us are interested in seriously debating? Current unfair dismissal legislation provides for the right of all employees to have access to appeal mechanisms against unfair, harsh or unreasonable dismissal. These regulations would take away that right for thousands of Australian workers—workers who have the misfortune to be employed by an operation with 15 or fewer employees. Ask yourself: why should workers in that situation have fewer rights than those who have the good fortune to work for larger organisations?

Mr Reith's new regulations mean that employees can be sacked summarily from such businesses without any redress. The regulations also mean that, if a person is employed for less than six months, they can also be sacked without redress, which opens the way to exploitation by employers. To add insult to injury, these regulations double the cost of the filing fee from $50 to $100 for an application for unfair or unlawful termination of employment. They also delete the sunset clause providing that the filing fee would cease to apply after 31 December 1998.

What a mean-spirited and spiteful measure this is. Its only impact will be to act as a deterrent against filing an application for unfair or unlawful termination. It is really just a case of kicking someone while they are down, kicking someone even harder while they are down by slugging them with an unnecessarily burdensome fee when they have just lost their job.

Mr Reith announced his gazettal in the usual Reith style, by press release, at the start of the most recent Gulf crisis when the US launched its attack on Baghdad. We have correctly, I think, described this act as cowardly and too smart by half, in that it conveniently ensured that the timing was right to avoid scrutiny not only by the media but also by the parliament, which is part of Peter Reith's strategy.

talk.start.para: —What have they got to hide?

—Don't forget that there is actually legislation in the pipeline to address this government's policy; it is in the parliamentary forum already. These regulations are simply Peter Reith's way of avoiding Senate scrutiny.

speech.para: The opposition does not intend to let the government get away either with avoiding Senate scrutiny or with their attack on Australian workers. That is why we have proposed, and are willing to argue out sensibly, this disallowance motion. This is the first opportunity the Senate has had to formally consider these regulations. The opposition believes that it is vitally important that the Senate disallow these inequitable regulations as quickly as possible, not least because of the uncertainty surrounding the application of the regulations. Numerous lawyers have warned against using the new regulations prior to scrutiny in the Senate and a decision on this disallowance motion. Employers may find themselves in a legal quagmire if they exercise the new regulations because, of course, the disallowance will apply retrospectively.

I would like to reiterate a point I made when I last spoke on this issue, and that is that this legislation amends the Howard government's own unfair dismissal laws. The government's much touted Workplace Relations Act extensively amended the unfair dismissal laws and came into effect on 1 January 1997. John Howard and Peter Reith have boasted that their new system for unfair dismissals is a `simpler, more balanced system that provides a fair go all round'.

There is nothing fair about this exemption for small business; an exemption that discriminates against employees who work for a small business employer with fewer than 15 employees and employees who have been employed for less than six months. If Mr Howard and Mr Reith believe that their own unfair dismissal laws are so simple and balanced and provide a fair go all round, why do they need to pursue this exemption for small business? The government continues to insist that this exemption will boost employment by removing apparent disincentives for small businesses to hire new staff, but this argument has no tangible evidence at all to support it.

A paper by Peter Waring and Alex De Rutye of the University of Newcastle, presented to the Airaanz 1999 Conference in Adelaide earlier this month, examined employment data to identify whether unfair dismissal legislation had, in fact, prevented jobs growth. They found that, notwithstanding unfair dismissal regulation, employment data revealed strong job creation and aggregate job growth in small business. In November last year, Minister Reith quoted the 1997 National Institute of Labour Studies report commissioned by DEETYA, which identified trends in staff selection and recruitment. Mr Reith stated that the NILS report `found that unfair dismissal laws strongly influenced hiring decisions'. However, Waring and De Rutye reveal that the very same report identified that less than half the respondents—48 per cent—thought that unfair dismissal laws influenced hiring decisions to a large or very large extent.

So what do we have here from Penthouse Pete? A bit of selective quoting—which is what you normally see from the government to try to justify the unjust. The same authors also quote the Telstra Yellow Pages Small Business Survey of August 1998. The survey posed the question: what are the barriers to taking on new employees? That was posed to over 1,200 small business proprietors. At August 1998, 41 per cent saw no barriers to employment growth. The 59 per cent who identified barriers did not even rate unfair dismissal laws with a specific mention.

The unfair dismissal laws may have been considered in this survey under two other categories—employment conditions or red-tape/regulations—however, these combined only comprised 17 per cent of identified barriers to taking on new employees. Another question actually posed by this survey is more directly informative. Small business proprietors were asked: what are the most important small business issues for government? Only six per cent identified unfair dismissal laws. Of course, without any tangible evidence at all to support their claim that the unfair dismissal laws act as a hindrance to employment within small business, the only justification that the government has is this ideological obsession with dismantling the rights of Australian workers that we have seen since the government was elected in 1996. That is what is driving these proposals.

What about genuine government assistance for small business and the government's commitment to reduce the burden of red tape? I think John Howard is just kidding himself if he thinks that this legislation will solve the problems and relieve the burdens of small business. I would like to quote one last point from Waring and De Rutye. They concluded:

Finally, the government's plan to exclude those businesses employing 15 or less persons will create some interesting situations. For example, a firm with 15 employees will enjoy the exemption until they decide to employ a new person. This may mean that an employee's rights would fluctuate with the changing employment levels of the business. Moreover, to retain their exemption some firms may maintain their work forces at 15 or less persons. Alternatively, the law may encourage some firms to downsize their work force so as to attract the exemption. These outcomes would hardly be conducive to employment growth.
Oh, really? The government's only argument for pursuing these exemptions has been job creation. Yet they may well have the adverse effect—
Senator Alston interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You are just starting to listen now to the debate, are you? These regulations and the underhanded way that they were introduced are another betrayal of the Australian people. Do not forget this government's broken promises and how over the last couple of years they have really revealed their true colours on many issues of importance to Australians. The government, as senators would know, wooed voters with weasel words and rhetoric about delivering to families. They wooed voters with weasel words about protecting the poor, the needy and the vulnerable in our community. They wooed voters with weasel words about guaranteeing that no worker would be worse off under the new industrial relations regime of the coalition government.

speech.para: John Howard and Peter Reith promised to give workers a right of appeal if they had been unfairly dismissed. What they did not say is that, if you happen to work for a small business, that promise just does not count. You have got no right of appeal in that circumstance. All workers in that situation have been betrayed yet again by the Howard government because, if you do appeal, they are going to slug you by doubling the filing fee for an application for unfair or unlawful termination of employment. Of course this is at a time when workers, ordinary Australians, have a cash flow crisis. Most people, except those born with a silver spoon in their mouth and the coalition frontbench, would understand that. It is pretty clear what the government are up to here.
I think it is important to place on the public record what the government has said in relation to unfair dismissal. As the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard said:
I'm not going to have a law where an unreasonable employer can capriciously sack a decent, hardworking employee.
In one of his headland speeches, he said:

Let me make a hard and fast commitment that when we win government we will ensure that Australia has a balanced unfair dismissal provision which is fair to both employers and employees. We won't tolerate unreasonable dismissals.
Mr Reith said that the redrafted system of unfair dismissals would not contain any exemptions. He said on 28 February 1996:
Our position is very clear. If you have been unfairly dealt with at work, then you should have a right of appeal.
Of course they did not qualify it at all. They have broken these commitments to the Australian people and Australian workers.

The impact of these regulations goes to the very core of the lives of all working Australians and their families. There is a very strong link between a worker's role in the work force and the quality of life that is enjoyed by a worker's family and children. John Howard promised to provide security and certainty to families. These regulations do an awful lot to dismantle the security of employment that workers hope to enjoy. Of course, security of employment is fundamental to the security workers have as a family. We do not think it is something that John Howard or this government should be messing with.

Parliament has made a ruling on these exemptions. The Senate has expressed its will twice by rejecting the government's unfair dismissal exemption legislation so the government has tried to revisit the matter through the back door. Let me say that our position on this remains unchanged. I urge the Senate to stand by its earlier resolution and vote to disallow these sneaky and underhanded regulations that are so typical of the way this government does business.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Jacinta Collins's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report to the Attorney-General, entitled Administrative review of patents decisions , deals with the very important issue of intellectual property. Intellectual property is that sort of property which now enriches countries around the world, so it is important not only as an issue of fairness but also as an issue of great economic moment. It is an issue of fairness because people who establish a new way of doing things or who invent a new object—for example, a new type of bicycle seat, which may seem simple but which requires a lot of thought and development if it is going to be built the right way and serve the purpose the inventor wants—need to have those things protected.

The situation at the moment is that people who develop new ideas, new ways of doing things or a new object are not protected as they should be. That is not so much because of the law but because of the cost involved. It is very expensive to take out a patent that is effective not only in Australia but around the world, and that is what people have to do now to protect their intellectual property. To apply to take out a patent is very expensive because it has to be done from one country to another.

This report dealing with this very important matter should be read by all senators and by the public as a whole. To return to the theme I started with, unless the intellectual property that we have in Australia is protected—in the sense of what flows from it—and remains in Australian hands or remains in a way that benefits Australia, then we are losing too much to a world that is ever ready to take hold of the many ideas that develop here.

I was talking about a bicycle seat, and I was thinking of a young man I know who has developed such an object. He has had considerable difficulty maintaining the product of his mind around the world, because people outside Australia are so endowed with money that they can hold others off until their pa tents run out and they have to renew, and renew at great cost. This affects people like this young man I am thinking of and many others as well. This report to the Attorney-General about patents decisions, which seems at first sight to be a fairly dry subject, is a report that deals with one of the most vital issues that the parliament and the government face—that is, the proper protection of intellectual property developed in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Senator Cooney, as always, has made an erudite contribution to the debate in this chamber. The issue of intellectual property is a vexing issue for a range of reasons—none of which are ideological, I would dare say—but it constitutes a real challenge to our intellect itself to deal with them.

speech.para: Senator Cooney quite rightly raised the issue of what you do to preserve the Australian ownership of intellectual property. He alluded to the difficulty of raising capital in Australia or from sources overseas to invest in Australia to help people develop the full potential of their intellectual property. Intellectual property in and of itself is not worth anything unless it is sold or the idea behind it is developed, manufactured and sold to other people. The property right itself is a lovely bit of paper, but it is nothing more, and I think Senator Cooney appreciates that point. I would say that Senator Cooney is correct, but we also need to look at a number of other things.

One of those is the way in which we raise capital for investment in businesses. One of the concerns I have is that, when seed capital is put into a business to start it off—and we have seen some spectacular successes of start-up businesses in the last two years, particularly involving intellectual property and computers or Internet technology—the people who invest the seed capital will make the decision at some stage to withdraw their seed capital. In order words, the company has flourished and they want to take their profit and invest it somewhere else.

One of the problems we have in this country is that we have a very onerous capital gains tax regime which makes it less attractive to put seed capital into a company in Australia than it might be elsewhere. If I am a private investor, the profit I make when I sell my seed capital two years down the track is taxed at 48½c in the dollar—the top marginal rate—in the year in which the profit was derived. In other countries, that high taxation regime is not present.

That has a very simple effect; it encourages people who have good intellectual property in Australia to start up the company and list it overseas because overseas investors get a more generous tax treatment in another country than they get here. That is one of the crises we have in terms of venture capital. The capital gains tax erodes the gains and, hence, encourages the movement of the domicile of those companies offshore. I think Senator Cooney would agree that that is not a desirable consequence, but that is one of the problems we must grapple with.

But the other problem we have to grapple with is a much more esoteric problem, and that is this: rigorous maintenance of intellectual property prevents the development of that idea by someone else down the track. When you have products that have a very limited life—for example, certain computer technologies, algorithms and so on which may become superseded—you need to be able to develop them quickly. I think that generates a general philosophical debate as to the length of intellectual property.

I do not want to get into that tonight, but that is also one of the issues which faces us as a legislature. How much protection do you give to the inventor and how much do you encourage the development of the idea? In many cases, good ideas can be made better ideas by development but, if you have intellectual property rights which are too restrictive, it prevents that development. In conclusion, I hope Senator Cooney manages to find a venture capitalist who will aid his friend's bicycle seat, as I hope that we find venture capital for many other great Australian inventions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
