talk.start.para: —This evening I want to speak about the appearance in March of Australia before the United Nations Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, so I am particularly pleased that Minister John Herron is in the chamber. Many senators will not be aware that there is a process which enables the UN committee responsible for the compliance of parties to the International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination to seek from countries their particular response when there is criticism of that country's policies, and tonight I want to detail some of these processes.

speech.para: At the meeting in Geneva in August last year, a draft decision prepared by Mr Banton, Mr Wolfrum and Mr van Boven was introduced stating that there were worrying developments in Australia regarding the situation of Aboriginal people. I cannot go through all of this debate at the United Nations CERD committee because it goes from points 29 to 51—over five pages. There was quite a considerable debate of concern, which I will summarise with this statement by Mr Wolfrum:

. . . the situation in Australia was clearly deteriorating. It was deeply regrettable that institutions such as the post of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, which the Committee had praised so highly in 1994, were disappearing. Aboriginals were being marginalized, their life expectancy was about 10 years less than that of the white population and the illiteracy rate among Aboriginals was approximately five times higher.

Similar concerns were expressed about the native title legislation and whether or not it complied with the convention—a debate which we had regarding the Racial Discrimination Act at the time of the debate in this place.

Tonight, in the spirit of reconciliation, I want to comment on how the government could maximise its appearance before the CERD committee as an opportunity to move forward in regard to the reconciliation process that the Prime Minister has committed himself to. A report has been prepared by the Attorney-General's Department and has been released. I have sought permission from the Government Whip to table the document and that has been granted. I now seek leave to table the Attorney-General's Department report.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —For those who would like to look at this document, it is available on the Attorney-General's web site. But I think it is important that honourable senators have the opportunity to read it. I have to say that it is not a comprehensive document; it is not a visionary document.

speech.para: If Australia is being asked to justify its position in relation to meeting the Convention on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, I would have thought the government would go out of its way to spell out its vision for the future, its vision for reconciliation. The Australian government is already about 2½ years overdue with its periodic report on how it is moving to implement policies that overcome racial discrimination, and it would seem that this was the perfect opportunity. Indeed, if you were as cynical as I am on such occasions, you could even argue that the govern ment could have deflected some of the attention about the two issues that the committee raised by focusing on its vision for reconciliation.

I find the document extremely disappointing. But I think there is still time for the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation—Phillip Ruddock—and you, Minister Heron, to retrieve the situation not only in terms of fundamental justice for Aboriginal people in this country but for Australia's international reputation.

On Australia Day this year, in an advertisement headed `It's Time for a Treaty', 57 Aboriginal leaders publicised their demand for `the Australian government to sign a treaty with Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islander peoples', stating that it `should be concluded by 26 January 2001 as a symbolic date for negotiated settlement between the nation and the indigenous peoples'. I know that this government has said all along—and in opposition it was also policy—that there would not be a treaty.

But politics is the art of compromise. The Prime Minister could give a public commitment to negotiating policy with indigenous people. For example, we could have negotiation here, out at the front of Parliament House, in relation to the tent embassy, instead of the confrontation that has developed. If, when Australia speaks at the United Nations on 12 March, there could be a statement of absolute commitment for negotiation, even that would be a major step forward.

Also, I believe the government could and should seriously reconsider the abolition of the position of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. It does not mean a lot of dollars; it is not a major step backwards in terms of government policy—and obviously I am looking at it from the government's point of view, not mine. But I am looking for realistic ways in which the government can set a new tone on 12 March in Geneva.

I am realistic; I know that there is no way this government will turn its back on the Wik legislation. So I predict that it will be criticised by the United Nations committee for that particular piece of legislation. So why not balance that criticism by trying to recognise the concerns and giving a commitment to reinstate the position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner?

In addition, I think an important issue is the selection of the Australian representative for Geneva. We do not yet know whether it will be a public servant—and, with every respect to public servants, I hope it is not. I believe that this is an opportunity, an occasion, for the attendance of a senior minister—the Attorney-General himself, Phillip Ruddock, even the Prime Minister. If the Prime Minister were really committed to reconciliation, if he were really concerned about the way in which Australia is being portrayed internationally as to its treatment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, then he himself would be there. That may seem a bit unrealistic, but I think it would be a very good opportunity.

I think it is appropriate that on that occasion the government make some very strong statements of commitment for the future—commitment to negotiation; for it to recommit to having the position of Social Justice Commissioner, which was seen by the United Nations as very innovative and forward looking; and commitment to genuine reconciliation which, of course, will involve recognition of ATSIC and reinstatement of many of the programs that are now so underfunded.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to once again bring to this chamber's attention the injustices that are inflicted on tertiary students around the country every day. I am speaking, of course, about compulsory student unionism. Like its workplace predecessor, it is a situation in which a student is forced to join and fund a union, whether it is overtly political or not, as a condition of entry into university. The proponents of compulsory student unionism, like the old guard left-wing proponents of closed-shop work practices, justify their arguments on the arrogant notion that the benefits of representation and some services are so important that people must be compelled to enjoy them.

speech.para: The logic of this approach is clearly absent. The obvious and irrefutable response to it is `that if something is so desirable, people will choose to pay for it without coercion'. It is around this statement that I would like to compare tonight the two models of voluntary unionism for students in Australia at present.

There are currently two states that have legislated to move towards voluntary student unionism. They are Western Australia and Victoria. Tonight I will briefly present the relative differences and successes of these two versions of VSU—the latter of which, indeed, I submit, is not voluntary student unionism. The former, the Western Australian model, stipulates that no compulsory fee may be levied for non-academic services as a condition of entry into university. This means that, if these non-academic activities are to be funded, they must be funded wholly by the students who choose to use them. This seems to upset a lot of unionists. No longer do they have the coercive threat of `no ticket, no start' or `no fee, no degree' hanging over students' heads.

Now student unions, or guilds as they are called in Western Australia, are ceasing to fund activities that students genuinely dislike or do not support. Why? Because, when the union ceases to represent its members satisfactorily, its members will vote with their feet and their dollars and they will leave. So what has happened in Western Australia? That depends on where you choose to look. If you look at Curtin University, the guild has gone from strength to strength. With high profitability and strong union membership, the guild has been a success story. As for political activism, that has taken a back seat. This apparently causes no end of frustration to the activists left at Curtin because their demands for the usual fringe activity go unheeded.

This is quite different to the Edith Cowan University Guild. The ECU Guild has struggled since VSU was introduced. Most recently it was asking for a bailout of well over a hundred thousand dollars from the university to help keep it afloat. Unlike the Guild at Curtin, the ECU Guild chose a course of political activism. The students at Edith Cowan University, like those at Curtin Uni versity, did not consider this so-called representation a service worth paying for. So they haven't. This is hardly surprising. Students do not want their money being spent by political zealots on bizarre campaigns. They want services, taverns, legal advice, student sports centres, clubs and societies to name a few. In Western Australia they get them all. Why? Not because they are compelled but because they have chosen to fund them. This is not an abstract prediction, it is a fact.
Allow me to quote, for example, directly from the University of Western Australia Student Guild home page. It reads:

The UWA Student Guild is committed to providing the best educational, social and financial benefits to its members. The Guild offers many services to students including the Guild Shop, Education Office, Catering, Copy Shop, Second-Hand Book Shop and much more.

The list goes on. You do not have to force students to have fun! Naturally, some services and forms of representation will have decreased in output, but only to the extent that they now reflect the desires of an informed, articulate student membership. Representation, the primary service of most trade unions and the National Union of Students, is one of those services which has had a decline in demand. Quite clearly, these informed, articulate and intelligent students feel capable of representing themselves.

The Western Australian model has resulted in massive savings for students. Typically, voluntary fees paid have more than halved which is great news for all students, but it is especially great news for those students who are struggling to be at university. The old compulsory student union fee did not discriminate between rich and poor. It was a highly regressive poll tax. Through the course of the year, you either got your money's worth in services or you didn't. That is, you were either a net subsidiser of other people or the student body was a net subsidiser of you. Those in the know—the active members of the union—usually profited the most. Those students who focused on their degrees, their careers, their part-time jobs or other outside interests generally lost. It is important to remember that this wasn't means tested.

Across the country in the state of Victoria the situation is quite different. In Victoria, the compulsory union fee is still levied on behalf of student unions by universities, but the legislation prescribes what this money may and may not be spent on. In the language of the act these categories are `allowed' and `non-allowed'. This situation is a classic example of taxation without representation. Union fees have not been reduced at all. All of the old inefficiencies still exist.

It gets even worse. Unlike in the west, where students can choose to fund the activities that they want, in Victoria students have already been forced to pay significant sums of money—often well over $300 per year.

There are other flaws in the Victorian model that prevent it from being genuinely voluntary. There are the practical problems of compliance. More bluntly, there are loopholes in the legislation big enough to drive a minibus full of Trots through. The Victorian branch of the National Union of Students has legal advice to the effect that the `allowed' part of the compulsory union fee at some campuses may be used to fund the National Union of Students. This is extraordinary. The complex and often dubious accounting practices by unions and the ambiguity of the legislation often combine to allow cross-subsidies between `allowed' and `non-allowed' bank accounts. Pouring money into an unprofitable, yet `allowed', activity, on the one hand, and taking the so-called profits from this to spend on `non-allowed' activities, on the other hand, are commonplace in Victoria—and virtually unenforceable.

This week, for example, the student union at Monash University Clayton campus, the Monash Students Association, is attempting to disaffiliate the local Liberal Club on an administrative technicality. One is hardly stunned that this will occur on Wednesday morning just before Orientation Week, when the Liberal Club at Monash was about to launch a major campaign in favour of the government's GST package and policy on voluntary student unionism. Coincidence or convenience?

There are some things that the Western Australian model can ensure that the Victorian model will never be able to do. The most important of these is to guarantee that student union membership and funding will be genuinely voluntary. This is guaranteed in Western Australia by the single voluntary union fee. In Victoria, at best, students can only hope that their compulsory fee only gets spent on activities that they support. But in the end, they will probably never know. Unless this parliament legislates for full voluntary student unionism, there is probably nothing that they will ever be able to do about it. Compulsory student unionism must be destroyed, and it must be destroyed soon.

talk.start.para: —History demonstrates that the people must constantly guard against abuses of power by the political executive. Failure to do this has contributed to some of the most appalling atrocities committed this century. That is why all advanced democracies pay a great deal of attention in their constitutional foundation to how those in the highest positions of authority can be removed and replaced. Just how any future Australian head of state could be dismissed and by whom is a central issue in our republic debate. The Constitutional Convention's model requires us to ask how much extra power Australians are prepared to give their political executive, to the Prime Minister, in particular.

speech.para: Dismissal of a President in the United States, as was recently seen, is subject to a carefully constructed series of legislative and judicial checks and balances. It contrasts starkly with the excessive powers proposed for the Australian Prime Minister under the Constitutional Convention's model. Contrary to claims made in support of it, this model did not enjoy an outright majority at last year's convention. But it was chosen by the Prime Minister to be put to referendum. And why wouldn't he like it? He would get powers under this model that no other Prime Minister in an advanced democracy could dream of.

A comparison of the dismissal procedures in the Constitutional Convention's model with the procedures in other nations reveals the unprecedented dismissal powers proposed for the Australian Prime Minister. In Singapore and South Africa the President may be removed from office only following a resolution of parliament supported by a two-thirds majority of all members. In Israel, a three-quarters majority of the Knesset must support the motion. In bicameral parliaments, such as Ireland and India, removing the President requires a charge of misbehaviour be brought before either house of the parliament. Dismissal must be passed in that house by a two-thirds majority. Following this, the other house investigates the charge and only on an absolute majority of two-thirds is the President then removed from office.

The bicameral USA system requires the House of Representatives to vote to direct the House Judiciary Committee to investigate charges against the President. Following this, the President is either cleared of the charges or the Judiciary Committee votes to send articles of dismissal to the full House of Representatives. If the House approves articles of dismissal, a trial is then conducted in the Senate, presided over by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court. A two-thirds majority of senators is required to remove the President from office.

In Germany, the President may be dismissed by the legislative assembly, Bundestag, or the council of state ministers, Bundesrat. A dismissal motion must be brought by at least one-quarter of members and must be carried by a two-thirds majority of the Bundestag or Bundesrat. To succeed it must then be prosecuted before the Federal Constitutional Court.

It can therefore be seen that in democratic countries worldwide presidents are removed either by parliaments or by a combination of parliaments and the courts. Further, wherever bicameral parliaments are involved, both houses of parliament are always involved in removal.

In contrast, the republican model presently proposed for Australia gives the Prime Minister summary and sole powers of dismissal, to be confirmed by the House of Representatives and not by the Senate. This is a poor safeguard. The House of Representatives is more correctly described as the `house of the executive'. The Prime Minister controls the cabinet, the cabinet controls the party in government, and they have the numbers to do whatever they please. The exclusion of the Senate, elected under proportional representation, is designed to ensure the political party in power has unfettered control of the dismissal power. That is not democratic; that is authoritarian.

Contrary to the parliamentary and judicial processes of other countries, the convention's model proposes that an Australian president may be removed at any time by a notice in writing issued by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister need not provide any reason for this decision—extraordinarily, no grounds for dismissal are outlined in the Constitutional Convention model. The president is removed immediately upon the Prime Minister's notice being issued. The Prime Minister's decision must be ratified by the House of Representatives within 30 days—as we all know, that is a very long time in politics! If the House does not ratify the Prime Minister's action, the president is not restored to office but is eligible for reappointment. Meanwhile a stand-in will assume the role of president, unless of course the stand-in happens to be a state Governor-General, in which case that state's Queen is again the head of state.

So, a Prime Minister hostile to a president may dismiss him or her at any time and has 30 days to explain this to the House of Representatives—which he, his cabinet and his party controls. If the House declines to ratify the Prime Minister's call, the president remains dismissed until reappointed by the parliament on recommendation by the Prime Minister. It is clear the Prime Minister retains complete control over this process from start to finish. Perhaps this is why Mr Howard's opposition to the republic is fairly muted—after all, he has so much to gain. And it may explain why Mr Beazley is so bullish on this model, because, after all, he too may have much to gain.

This unprecedented dismissal procedure, with its concentration of power proposed for the Prime Minister, flies in the face of the need for an Australian republic to be open, accountable and responsible to the people. It further erodes the separation of powers, further entrenches the power of the Prime Minister and cabinet and ignores repeated calls for the people or their elected representatives to be fully involved in the dismissal process. Why, for instance, exclude the Senate from the process of dismissal? And, based on international precedent, the Prime Minister should actually be excluded from the process, not made the boss of it.

Many in Australia have argued, in line with hard-won wisdom from overseas, that the president should only be removable by a vote of no confidence passed by a two-thirds majority resolution in both houses of parliament on grounds of stated misbehaviour or incapacity. The alleged misbehaviour or incapacity should be investigated and ruled upon by a judicial commission. It would be absurd if the president of our country were more easily removed than a judicial officer, yet this is precisely what is being proposed in the Constitutional Convention model.

Adequate involvement of the parliament in the dismissal of a president is a non-negotiable requirement of basic democratic fairness. The absolute lack of this involvement in the convention model highlights the need for the amendment of that model in the interests of furthering democracy and in the interests of advancing a republican model which will be more acceptable to the people than the one presently proposed.

talk.start.para: —(7.28 p.m.)—I today wish to pay tribute to a fine Australian and a fine Queenslander, Mr Laurie Rosenblum, who this year concluded a 50-year career with the Queensland Board of Jewish Deputies. Before I address this matter, I should, however, make mention of his activities prior to 1948 when he first moved to Queensland.

speech.para: Laurie Rosenblum, whom I have known for a number of years, was born in South Africa, but his family moved to Australia when he was young and Laurie spent most of his formative years in Western Sydney. Being a patriotic Australian, Laurie signed up for service in the Army during the Second World War and was selected as an officer. During his time in the Northern Territory he had his first contact with tribal Aboriginals, a contact which was to lead him to become a passionate advocate of Aboriginal enfranchisement.

At the cessation of hostilities Laurie served with the Army in the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces in Japan before returning to Australia and making his home with his wife, Hilma, in my home state of Queensland.

Faced with the twin challenges of fighting discrimination and helping the Holocaust survivors settle in Brisbane, Laurie and a number of friends formed the Queensland Jewish Board of Deputies. He also served as Queensland Chairman of the Jewish Welfare Society, which established a temporary transit centre for refugees in Highgate Hill. Since 1948, Mr Rosenblum has spent 40 years as Chairman of the Public Relations Committee for the Board of Deputies, 44 years as councillor and five years as President.

His concern has never been limited to those of his own faith. Laurie was an early and determined campaigner for the rights of Aboriginals. This led directly to the 1967 referendum sponsored by the coalition government to extend the full rights of citizenship to Aboriginals. More recently, Laurie was a forthright critic of racism and extreme politics, which he saw as perpetuating the old hatreds and evils which he had fought against so vigorously in the Second World War. Through all of these momentous challenges, he has been compassionate, fair and restrained—always seeking to find common ground rather than ongoing division. He has been extremely active in veterans affairs, especially the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces veterans. He is the national vice-president of the BCOF association and it is noteworthy that a lunch held in his honour in Brisbane on Sunday was attended by the national president.

Laurie Rosenblum's contribution to the Queensland and Australian community has been recognised by the award of an OAM but, more importantly, by the recognition of his fellow citizens that he is a friend to the weak and a valiant campaigner for what is right. Moreover, anyone who has met him would also say Laurie Rosenblum is a good bloke. Laurie has vowed to stay active in community affairs but few would deny that it would take an extraordinary person, or even a team of people, to fill his shoes. Let us hope, for all our sakes, those people can be found. Laurie Rosenblum, on behalf of a grateful Australia, thank you very much.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I wish to support Senator Boswell in his statement about Laurie Rosenblum. He is an outstanding Queenslander who has made a contribution to our state that is unequalled in its history.

speech.para: Madam Deputy President, I rise to my feet tonight to respond, in part, to Senator Reynolds, who spoke earlier in the adjournment debate about our vision for reconciliation. I want to respond in the spirit in which she made her contribution. I was a little concerned that Senator Reynolds spoke of her cynicism. I do not believe that Senator Reynolds is cynical; I think that she has made a great contribution over the years and I have not, at any stage, seen any evidence of cynicism.

She made a plea for justice for Aboriginal people. She spoke about the 57 people whom she termed Aboriginal leaders and who, amongst others, signed an advertisement on Australia Day calling for a treaty. She spoke about politics being the art of compromise. She spoke about other matters in relation to my portfolio. I want to refute some of those statements that she made, in the same spirit in which she made them.

The first is that I do not believe that politics is the art of compromise. My good friend Sir James Killen always quotes Edmund Burke, who said about politics, `that which is not practicable is spurious'. I differ with Sir James, who quotes that frequently; I believe that politics is about leadership. All of us, as parliamentarians, are privileged to be here and it is incumbent on us to show leadership. While I respect what Senator Reynolds has said, there is a greater dimension to it.

She spoke also about the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Peoples. I attended Geneva on one occasion, in 1996, and I was just amazed to see and learn that only 60 indigenous peoples are actually represented now in the United Nations—such has been the confluence of history in their destruction. But activists use the vehicle of the United Nations to put their own view and expect Australians to cringe because criticism comes from overseas. In reality, Australia has an outstanding record of human rights and indigenous people in Australia are free to fully exercise their human and civil rights. I think that all of us who have had the opportunity to travel overseas and even work in some of the disadvantaged nations realise what a wonderful country we have here—what opportunities exist for people, no matter what their race.

I agree with Senator Reynolds that we must recognise our past. However, we must also understand the present. More importantly, we have to think of the future. There is so much that we can achieve together in that spirit of reconciliation. I would ask Senator Reynolds to continue to make her contribution in that regard but to think not of living in the past in recognising the injustices that have occurred to the Aboriginal people. The horrific history of dispossession and the cruelties that were inflicted upon them is recognised by all; but we must also understand the present, insofar as there are, in Australia today, more than 200 racial and ethnic groups. There are 53 languages spoken as the first language in family groups which have English as a second language. There are over 40 different religions practised in Australia today. We have a melting pot of society in Australia that is unequalled in the world. I think the fact that we are the sixth oldest continuous democracy in the world speaks for itself. We have a wonderful future. We have demonstrated to the world that we are able to absorb people from all the nations of the world. But I do not believe that anything is gained, when we are planning for the future and showing leader ship for the future, by dwelling on the injustices of the past, to the detriment of the future.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 23 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that there have been 23 dugong mortalities in 1998, the same number of mortalities as in 1997 before dugong protected areas (DPAs) were implemented.
(2) (a) How many of these mortalities were due to gill netting; and (b) can gill netting be conclusively ruled out as a cause of death for any of the 23 dugongs.
(3) Given that the dugong death rate has not declined with the implementation of DPAs, will a review be conducted into the adequacy of these areas.

(4) Given that Zone A DPAs do not permit netting: (a) if dugong mortalities due to netting have been reported in these areas, will the Minister consider upgrading them from Zone B, where netting is permitted, to Zone A. k,

(5) Will the Minister consider declaring further DPAs in areas that were originally recommended for inclusion by independent experts, particularly where dugong mortalities may have occurred in 1998, indicating that such recommendations should be acted on.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Twenty-seven confirmed dugong carcasses (not including animals taken legally by indigenous hunters) have been reported in Queensland for the year to 30 November 1998, compared with 28 and 32 confirmed mortalities reported in Queensland for the same period in 1996 and 1997 respectively. The 1998 deaths comprise 12 from within the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area; 10 from within the Hervey Bay and the Great Sandy Straits region; and 5 from the Moreton Bay region.

It is important to note that, since the implementation of Dugong Protected Areas in January 1998, there has been no confirmed deaths as a result of gill netting in any of the Zone A DPAs or Zone B DPAs.

(2) (a) Determinations on the cause of death have been made for 10 of the 27 dugong carcasses. In two instances drowning in a gill net has been identified as a cause of death, one near Cairns and one at Midge Point north of Mackay. Other identified causes were:
. disease (confirmed for one animal from Hervey Bay, and assessed as probable for another animal from Hervey Bay and one from Moreton Bay);
. boat strike (in two cases from Moreton Bay);
. non-permitted hunting (confirmed for one case from Clairview near Mackay);
. research (one death during research in Moreton Bay with an assessment that the animal died `probably as a result of an existing heart disease'); and
. a `probable human-related cause' (identified by the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage for a carcass near Townsville).
(b) The precise cause of deaths was unable to be determined for 17 of the 27 dugong because the carcasses were too decomposed or they were unable to be removed for necropsy.

(3) Since the establishment of DPAs in January 1998, there have been fewer confirmed deaths due to gill netting along the Queensland coast. In particular, there have been no confirmed deaths in DPAs due to gill netting.

In any event, the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council is committed to ongoing review of the success of the emergency measures to protect dugong on the Great Barrier Reef. This ongoing review will include an examination of the effectiveness of surveillance and enforcement activity in the DPAs. I am pleased to say that an additional $230 000 has been provided recently by the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments through the Ministerial Council to increase surveillance and enforcement in the DPAs. This is expected to result in an additional 132 vessel patrols and 75 surveillance flights into the DPAs in the first half of 1999, together with special project and educational operations. The Commonwealth Government has also promised to provide an extra $3.4 million over 3 years to enhance surveillance and enforcement in the Great Barrier Reef
The ongoing review will address all causes of death including gill netting.
(4) Dugong mortalities due to netting had not been confirmed in any of the DPAs, including Zone B DPAs, to the end of November 1998.

(5) The Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council is committed to ongoing review of the measures it has instituted for the conservation of dugongs in the Great Barrier Reef and adjacent areas and has not ruled out any additional courses of action for that purpose.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that the decision to transfer to digital transmission has resulted in rural and regional communities being required to purchase a new system of receiving radio and television signals.

(2) Is the Minister aware that this change in remote satellite services will cost these communities up to $6,500 per decoder and that some of these communities currently use three different decoders or more and that the subsidy available to these communities is only in the range of $2,500 to $3,500 for each decoder.

(3) Why are these rural and regional communities forced to bear the added burden of the cost of replacing these decoders when Australians in metropolitan areas receive the same television and radio signals at no cost to the individual communities, particularly given the reliance on these services in such remote communities.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Optus has previously delivered television and associated radio services by analogue satellite transmission to remote areas of Australia, beyond the reach of terrestrial transmission networks. Reflecting worldwide trends, Optus has decided for commercial reasons to digitise its satellite operations, including the delivery of remote area broadcasting services (RABS). Digital conversion of RABS services is occurring progressively this year and is currently scheduled to be completed by mid 1999.

Optus' decision necessitates the replacement of existing analogue decoders with digital units to continue to receive RABS. I understand that existing satellite dishes should in most cases be able to receive the digital signal without modification. This also applies to RABS digital transmissions by Telstra, using the PanAmSat PAS 2 satellite, in Western Australia. In the deregulated satellite and communications market, Telstra has competed with Optus for the digital transmission of RABS.

(2)—(3) The Government is making a significant contribution to ease the transition for remote area viewers to digital RABS transmission, even though transmission arrangements are primarily commercial matters for the industry. Technological changes must be expected over time to satellite delivery of broadcasting services, just as changes occur to terrestrial broadcasting—such as the conversion from black and white to colour television and the planned move to digital terrestrial television broadcasting.

Reflecting the Government's strong commitment to regional Australia, in November 1997 I announced an $11.2 million package under the Government's $250 million Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund (RTIF) to subsidise the cost of digital decoders in remote areas. The independent RTIF Board set aside $8 million for this assistance from within the Fund, to which the Federal Government added a further $3.2 million.

The RTIF Board has determined that a subsidy of $750 is payable for the replacement of each existing analogue decoder in households with direct to home (DTH) reception, $2,500 for replacement of each analogue decoder at community self-help retransmission sites, and $3,500 for replacement of decoders at remote Aboriginal community retransmission sites. These subsidies represent a significant contribution towards meeting the cost of digital decoders which, I understand, retail for about $1,000, in the case of DTH units, and $3,500—$6,500 for most retransmission units.

For the subsidised cost of digital decoders, remote area viewers will also obtain access, for the first time, to national satellite-delivered ABC Triple J and Parliamentary and News Network radio services, and satellite-delivered SBS television in remote and regional Western Australia. Digital decoders also afford potential access to internet, data transfer and pay TV as these services are developed in regional areas. The Government is making a major separate contribution through the RTIF to facilitate the availability of online services in regional Australia through a range of projects.

The Government remains committed to further improving the quality and range of broadcasting services available to Australians, within the limits imposed by competing national budget priorities, and to ensuring equitable access to such services in regional Australia.

During the recent election campaign, the Government announced that it would establish a $120 million Television Fund to extend SBS television to transmission areas of more than 10,000 people, and to fix major "black spots" where the reception of television services is currently unavailable or where the quality of transmission is poor. The Television Fund will be established from the proceeds of the planned sale of a further 16 per cent of Telstra.

Legislation for the introduction of digital terrestrial television broadcasting services, which are scheduled to commence in regional areas between 1 January 2001 and 1 January 2004, provides for a review into whether any amendments to laws are needed to ensure that underserved regional communities are provided with up to the same number of commercial television services as are provided in metropolitan areas. The review is required to be conducted by 1 January 2000.

(11) If the Minister claims that there is a safety net, why did it not prevent the attempted removal of Mr SE.

(12) Can details be provided of: (a) what has happened to the 19 Somali nationals who were removed from Australia in September and October 1998; (b) the circumstances of their removal; (c) where and how are they now; (d) how they were removed to Somalia; (e) how long they were in countries before being returned; (f) were they in custody; (g) in whose custody were they held; (h) under what authority; and (i) are they in safe physical and mental condition.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) is a non-adversarial body and legal representation is not necessary during an RRT hearing. Only the applicant has a statutory right to appear before the RRT and give evidence. The Tribunal is not required to allow any other person to address it orally about the issues arising in relation to the decision under review. As a detainee, Mr SE was offered assistance at public expense in accordance with the contract for the Immigration Advice and Application Assistance Scheme. Under this scheme the contracting migration agent is required to assist with the preparation and lodgement of an RRT application but is not generally required to be present at RRT hearings. Asylum seekers are not bound to accept offers of application assistance and are free to make whatever arrangements they wish to obtain alternative or further assistance in pursuing their claims.
(2) Yes, in writing on 22 May 1998.
(3) My power under s417 is non-delegable and non-compellable. I will consider exercising my s417 power only when I consider it may be in the public interest to do so.

(4) (a) There is no legislative obligation to inform a detainee of their date of removal from Australia. However, Mr SE had repeated notifications of removal over a three week period leading up to 19 November 1998.

Mr SE was advised in writing on 23 October 1998 that he was to be removed. On 30 October 1998, he was given a further notice advising him of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs' (DIMA) intention to remove him and on 16 November 1998, DIMA officers informed Mr SE's solicitor that the detainee would be removed within days.

(b) Mr SE was not prevented from contacting his legal representatives. When DIMA officers informed Mr SE at the Maribyrnong IDC of his removal arrangements on Thursday 19 November 1998, he did not ask to speak to his solicitor. He was taken to Melbourne Airport by DIMA officers with Australasian Correctional Management escorts and boarded a Qantas flight to Perth.

Upon his arrival at Perth, senior DIMA officers interviewed Mr SE, as a complaint had been lodged on his behalf with the United Nations Committee Against Torture (UNCAT). Present at the interview was a representative from the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office in Perth. Mr SE was given the option of proceeding on the scheduled flight to South Africa or to proceed to the Immigration Reception Centre at Port Hedland, the closest appropriate immigration detention facility, pending the outcome of an inquiry into his circumstances by the UNCAT. Mr SE chose to stay in Australia and await the outcome of the UNCAT inquiry.
(6) Under the Migration Act 1958, removal of Mr SE is the responsibility of the airline carrier which brought him to Australia.

(7) The Government did not warn Amnesty International of serious consequences of campaigning on Mr SE's case. The Government contacted Amnesty International to draw their attention to an order, made by the Federal Court with the consent of Mr SE's counsel, that prohibited the publication of Mr SE's name and any information which might identify him.

Amnesty International had issued an alert disclosing Mr SE's name and other identifying information on the same day that the order was made by the Federal Court. Amnesty International was advised that `serious consequences could flow from the failure to observe such an order'. That is, that the breach of a court order is a serious matter which can result in criminal charges.
(8) Mr SE has been informed that there is no intention to remove him from Australia before the UNCAT has completed its consideration.

(10) A safety net does exist. All people determined not to be refugees by the RRT are assessed against my Guidelines for the identification of cases where I may consider it to be in the public interest to grant a visa.

The Guidelines refer to "persons whose particular circumstances or personal characteristics provide a sound basis for a significant threat to their personal security, human rights or human dignity on return to their country of origin."
Cases that are assessed as falling within these Guidelines are referred to me for my consideration of whether or not I consider it would be in the public interest to grant a visa in the case.

In addition, if a person writes to me seeking exercise of my public interest powers their case and any additional information is assessed afresh against the Guidelines and is brought to my attention so that I may consider whether to consider substituting a more favourable decision in their case.

(11) At the time that Mr SE's removal commenced, Mr SE's case had been assessed against my Guidelines on four (4) different occasions. It had been drawn to my attention on three (3) different occasions and I had declined to consider the exercise of my s417 power on each of those occasions. The safety net process operated as intended.
(12) (a) No follow up enquiries have been made concerning the whereabouts of Somalis removed from Australia.

(b) A group of 22 Somali nationals arrived in Australia in November 1997 using forged immigration documentation and were refused immigration clearance. They were detained in accordance with the Migration Act while their applications for protection visas were considered. Four were granted protection visas. Three of the group appealed to the Federal Court against the refusal of their protection visa applications. They remain in detention in Australia awaiting the outcome of their appeals. The remaining 15 persons were refused protection visas, did not appeal these decisions, and were removed from Australia in September 1998.
Three other Somali nationals who arrived without authorisation by air at different times were also removed in September and October 1998.
(c) The group of fifteen was returned to the cities of Mogadishu, Baidoa, Buleberde, Kismayo and Hargeisa in Somalia according to their preferences.

Of the other three Somali nationals, one was returned to Basoso, East Somalia. A second was returned to Kenya and the carrier advised that this person arranged, through a sponsor, a forward ticket to Mogadishu, Somalia, via Dubai. The third was returned to New Zealand, where he had a right to permanent residence.
Any subsequent movements made by the 18 Somalis are unknown to DIMA. No information is known about their personal circumstances.
(d) By air. In accordance with the Migration Act, removal is the responsibility of the airline company that brought each person to Australia without authorisation to do so.
Therefore, the carrier responsible for bringing the group to Australia made all the arrangements for the group's removal.

The group of 15 was escorted to South Africa by the Australian private security firm, Chubb. The onward travel from South Africa was arranged by the South African firm, Protecting & Indemnity (P&I). P&I company was also contracted to obtain the necessary Somali travel documents.
The three other Somali nationals were removed separately by the responsible carriers at the individual's written request.

The group of 15 was removed from Australia (to South Africa in the first instance) in small groups. Five departed on 5 September 1997; three departed on 15 September; four departed on 17 September; two departed on 19 September and one departed on 21 September.
The whole group of 15 then travelled from South Africa to Somalia, via Kenya on a charter flight on 7 October 1998.

Of the three other Somali nationals, one was removed directly to Basoso, East Somalia, on 11 September 1998. A second was removed to Kenya on 22 October 1998. The third was removed to New Zealand on 4 October 1998.

(e) Due to their different departure dates from Australia, members of the group spent between 15 and 31 days in South Africa prior to their departure from South Africa on 7 October. All spent a night in Kenya en route to Somalia.

Of the three other Somali nationals, one returned directly to Somalia, one spent an undetermined amount of time in Kenya before continuing private travel to Somalia via Dubai and the other did not return to Somalia.
(f) No.
(g) P&I accommodated the group in South Africa pending receipt of Somali travel documents and the charter flight to Somalia. There were no accommodation arrangements for the individuals.
(h) The group was accommodated under the arrangements made by P&I and the South African government authorities. There were no arrangements for the individuals.

(i) P&I reported that all members in the group were in good health and spirits on the day they arrived in Somalia. There is no information about the three other Somali nationals, but each requested in writing to be removed.
